Woolly Mammoth: The Woolly Mammoth was a large, extinct mammal that lived in North America and Eurasia during the Pleistocene epoch. I would choose to bring it back to life because of its unique features and its role in shaping the ecosystem. Woolly Mammoths were known for their thick fur, which provided warmth and protection from the harsh winter conditions. They also played an important role in shaping the landscape by breaking trees and creating paths through the forest.

Dodo: The Dodo was a flightless bird that lived on the island of Mauritius. I would choose to bring it back to life because of its unique appearance and its role in the ecosystem. The Dodo was a flightless bird that was unable to escape predators, and it became extinct as a result. However, it played an important role in the ecosystem by eating insects and other small animals, which helped to control their populations.

Tasmanian Tiger: The Tasmanian Tiger was a marsupial that lived in Australia and Tasmania. I would choose to bring it back to life because of its unique appearance and its role in the ecosystem. The Tasmanian Tiger was a marsupial that was able to climb trees and swim in water. It was also known for its distinctive stripes and its role as a predator of small animals.

Woolly Rhino: The Woolly Rhino was a large, extinct mammal that lived in North America and Eurasia during the Pleistocene epoch. I would choose to bring it back to life because of its unique features and its role in the ecosystem. Woolly Rhinos were known for their thick fur, which provided warmth and protection from the harsh winter conditions. They also played an important role in shaping the landscape by breaking trees and creating paths through the forest.

Platypus: The Platypus is a unique mammal that is native to Australia. I would choose to bring it back to life because of its unique appearance and its role in the ecosystem. The Platypus is a mammal that lays eggs instead of giving birth to live young. It is also known for its distinctive bill, which is covered in sensitive skin that can detect electrical signals from the muscle contractions of its prey.
